title: When They See Us stars urge Trump Administration to watch hit Netflix show
text:
The stars of Netflix show When They See Us have called on politicians to watch the series in hopes it will inspire them to fix the 'flaws' in the system.

The hit show, which was nominated for 16 Emmys, tells the story of the five Latino and Black teens - also known as the Central Park Five - who were wrongfully convicted of raping a white woman in 1989.

Speaking to DailyMail.com at the BAFTA Tea Party in Los Angeles, actor Asante Blackk, 17, who plays teen Kevin Richardson, said the show has already had an impact on some viewers who weren't aware of the historic case.

'A lot of people have said they didn't understand what was going on in the justice system until something like this came out,' Blackk said.

'We are telling these men's stories not just about the facts, but we are showing the emotions, the lives of their families and how it impacted their communities.

'And that's when it really starts to affect the people in power - at the end of the day we are all human. We should all come from a place of love and there is nothing better than that.'

Scroll down for video

When They See Us stars Asante Blackk (left) 17, and Ethan Herisse (right) 18, portray two of the Central Park Five in the hit Netflix show

Blackk, who plays Kevin Richardson (pictured right during his arrest in 1989) said the show has already had an impact on some viewers who weren't aware of the historic case

The show tells the story of the five Black and Latino boys who were wrongfully convicted of raping a white woman in Central Park in 1989. Ethan Herisse, plays Yusef Salaam, one of the teens who were accused

Blackk, who also plays Malik Hodges on NBC's This Is US, added: 'In terms of the lawmakers and judicial system, sometimes the system can turn a blind eye to these types of things and it is our job to wake them up and tell them: "we see what is going on here and we are not going to stand for it anymore".'

Blackk was joined by other cast members in giving impassioned views about the role of Hollywood in changing the conversation.

Blair Underwood, 55, who plays lawyer Bobby Burns, said a show's 'great artistry' is what can make a profound difference in the world and 'affect change.'

'I don't know if anybody in this White House is watching what we are creating and what Hollywood is doing,' he said, adding: 'I would say watch it.'

'The great thing about what we do as actors, directors and entertainers is that we can make people feel,' he told DailyMail.com.

'It is very different to seeing it on CNN, reading it in a book or newspaper, but it can make you connect with the characters and make you feel something. That is when you truly can affect change.'

He spoke of his pride that 'creative master' Ava DuVernay wrote and directed the 'gut-wrenching and heart wrenching extraordinary real life story'.

NYPD mug shots taken of the Central Park Five on April 23, 1989. Top Row (L-R): Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana. Lower Row (L-R) Kevin Richardson, Korey Wise, Antron McCray

When They See Us is directed by Ava DuVernay (center). She invited the Central Park Five (left to right: Raymond Santana, Kevin Richardson, Korey Wise, Antron McCray and Yusef Salaam) to the world premiere at The Apollo Theater in Harlem, New York

'That is what has reached into people's hearts... to let them see in this case these four young 14, 15, and 16-year-old boys and the way they were railroaded by the system.'

Underwood says the series pointed out a truth about 'the context of the world in which we live from the White House down.'

'There is a consciousness of race, race dynamics, our differences,' he explained, adding: 'Hopefully we will get through this one day and focus more on our unity.'

Ethan Herisse, who played Yusef Salaam, echoed his co-stars sentiments saying the show is meant to highlight a broken system.

'It brings the attention to a lot of flaws in our criminal justice system..which people like politicians have the power to fix.'

The 18-year-old added: 'I am hoping that they are seeing it and watching something like When they See Us inspires them to change and fix flaws and create different types of systems in government in general.'

Herisse reflected on the increased visibility of minorities in film and TV shows.

Blair Underwood, who plays lawyer Bobby Burns, urged the Trump Administration to watch the show - saying 'it is very different to seeing it on CNN, reading it in a book or newspaper'

'We are all human beings and we should be treated as such, no matter the color of your skin.

'The color of your skin doesn't define how much talent you have. You can do whatever you want to do.'

When They See Me was nominated in 16 categories at the Emmys.

Show creator Ava DuVernay honored the inspiration for the show by taking the real Central Park Five - Korey Wise, Antron McCray, Raymond Santana, Kevin Richardson, and Yusef Salaam - to the Emmy show in LA.

The actors who spoke to DailyMailTV joined a raft of major stars at the BAFTA Los Angeles TV Tea Party, presented by BBC America, at the Beverly Hilton.

The British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) is a world-leading independent arts charity that brings the very best work in film, games and television to public attention and supports the growth of creative talent in the U.K. and internationally.

For more information visit bafta.org/losangeles.
